carReveal.theArrow2Text: The Arrow2 was our car to the German championship. It crossed the finish line after 1.153 seconds and only weighs 55.1g with a length of 23.9cm.

shortTexts.whatIsStemRacing: STEM Racing is the worlds largest technology competition for students. It focuses on building a miniature Formular 1 car
shortTexts.aboutUs: We are the STEM Racing Team 'Ascent' from Hamburg, Germany and are going to the World Finals 2025 in Singapore.
shortTexts.theCar: This is our Arrow2, the car that helped us secure the title of the German Vice Champion. It’s the result of constant testing via CAE analysis, wind tunnel testing and real test drives.
shortTexts.sponsoring: We are looking for sponsors for the World Finals in Singapore.
shortTexts.gofundme: Support us on our journey to the STEM Racing World Finals in Singapore and help us succeed.

newsArticles.colorChangeText:
Ascent goes Magenta! We’ve updated our visual identity. As part of the rebranding, we made minor adjustments to the geometry of our logo to give it a cleaner, more modern look. Alongside this, we’ve changed our main team color from purple to a bold new magenta tone.
These changes are exclusively cosmetic - our passion, values, and goals remain the same.
newsArticles.germanViceText: On May 17th, we proudly became German Vice Champions and qualified for the Singapore World Finals 2025. The German Championship was an amazing experience. We met lots of kind and inspiring teams, and our car hit a run time of 1.155 seconds. A huge thank you to all our sponsors for making this possible. It was especially great to meet some of them, the Wilhelm Stemmer Stiftung and Ansys, at the event. We are now looking forward to continuing our journey and head to Singapore with Blue Wolves and Echo Racing. Let’s go Team Germany!
newsArticles.weAreHamburgerChapionText: At the Hamburger championship on the 22th of February 2025 we were able to win the first place and qualify for the German championship. Our car was the fastest of them all with a time of 1.203 seconds. We also won 5 special prices:
newsArticles.prepForDM: After winning the Hamburg Championship, we immediately started preparations for the German Championship the next day. At the kickoff meeting, we established slightly adjusted responsibilities and carried out time and budget planning. Currently, we are actively working on a prototype and sponsor acquisition. We are improving our laser measurement system and making initial decisions regarding our team booth.

aboutUs.title: About Us
aboutUs.text:
We are Team Ascent from Hamburg!
Our team consists of six students from Gymnasium Grootmoor, and together we have one goal: to become World champion. We named our team "Ascent" because the name symbolizes our motivation to rise - the constant drive to develop ourselves, aim higher, and grow beyond our limits together. Our race car is called "Arrow2", reflecting our mindset: precision, speed, and a clear direction - always moving forward. Our logo features two upward-pointing arrowheads that symbolize ascent. At the same time, you can also recognize the "A" from Ascent in the logo. We chose our signature shade of purple, #c53cf5, because it truly sets us apart and embodies the feeling of speed.

personIntroduction.benjamninText: As the team and project manager, I am responsible for task management, setting and meeting deadlines, as well as acquiring and supporting our sponsors. I also coordinate communication within the team. I always keep track of all tasks and continuously keep my teammates up to date. In my free time, I enjoy playing tennis and the saxophone.
personIntroduction.florianText: I take on the role of design engineer in our team. This makes me primarily responsible for developing our car using the CAD software Solid Edge, in compliance with the competition rules. I regularly carry out both virtual and real-world analyses of prototypes and test vehicles. An important part of my work also involves conducting research to support the design process. In my free time, I enjoy rowing and volunteering with the scouts.
personIntroduction.kjellText: I am responsible for our team's graphic design, especially the portfolios. I also create renderings of the car and produce our car reveal. Outside of STEM Racing, I enjoy flying FPV drones and I'm actively involved in the youth fire brigade.
personIntroduction.dariusText: My areas of responsibility are IT, the team booth, and electronics. I programmed and soldered our testing system and will design and build our team booth for the World Championship. In my free time, I enjoy inline skating.
personIntroduction.moritzText: During the preparations, I focus on the second most important element of the competition: the presentation. My hobbies are playing the piano and darts.
personIntroduction.vincentText: I joined Team Ascent after the Hamburg Championship. Since then, I have been managing our social media channels and designing all posts using Adobe Creative Cloud. I also support Darius with the team booth.

theCar.title: The Car

titles.forwardThrust: Forward thrust from the CO2 cartridge
titles.redirectionAirflow: Redirection of airflow behind the front wheels
titles.lcspwasf: Largely Convex Side Pod with Additional Side Foil

theCar.variants: In the following sections different side pod designs are shown:
theCar.introText: To appropriately understand the design of our car, we first have to clarify what forces apply on the car.
theCar.forwardThrustText: Stored in the cartridge are 8 grams of CO2 gas. As space in the chamber is limited, the gas inside is compressed and the pressure is high. When the cartridge is penetrated, gas releases at the back of the container. With Newton’s third law of motion (actio = reactio) it can be explained that the motion of the gas in one direction leads to a motion of the car into the other direction.
theCar.airResistanceText: Enzo Ferrari once said, “Aerodynamics are for people who can’t build engines.” Due to the technical regulations implemented by STEM Racing we’re not allowed to modify the accelerating force. Therefore, the quote from Enzo Ferrari doesn’t apply for STEM Racing and we focus on minimizing drag and optimizing components to ensure a fast track time without modifying the accelerating force. To minimize the drag coefficient, which is a value that puts into number, how streamlined an object is, we use various CFD analysis techniques. CFD stands for Computational Fluid Dynamics and one of the techniques we use is the combined flow visualisation. It combines the conventional streamline visualisation with the vector contour plot. The advantage of this technique is that it brings together both concepts to get a better understanding of the air’s direction of movement and at what speed the air moves. With this knowledge we can optimise the shape of the car’s components to make them more streamlined (= lower the drag coefficient). Another technique we use is the drag analysis. With this type of CFD analysis you can calculate the drag coefficient. Additionally, there are various other important CFD analysis techniques that we will not discuss here.
theCar.frictionOfWheelsText: Another force stopping the car is the friction between the rotating wheels and the fixed part of the axle construction. To minimise the friction between these components, we use ball bearings. Testing different ball bearings and axle constructions is a crucial part of real-life testing, because it is hardly possible to simulate the axial forces acting on the ball bearings and the wear of different ball bearing models and manufacturers.
theCar.introTextDesignProcess: To get a better understanding of our design process, we sectioned it into three aspects:
theCar.earodynamicsText:
Aerodynamic research and development (CFD analysis)
In this section we will show you our design process on the example of our side pods. To understand the design of our car’s side pods, we first need to clarify their function.
theCar.redirectionAirflowText: The primary goal of the side pod is to guide the airflow behind the open volume of the front wheels away from the rear wheels. Additionally, the side pods should prevent the unavoidable turbulent air created in the wake of the front wheels from interfering with laminar flow areas further downstream.
theCar.outwardFlowingSidePodText: The most straightforward side pod concept redirects the turbulent airflow behind the front wheels outward. This setup allows for the creation of a clean tunnel in the centre of the car in which no turbulence occurs. However, the combined flow visualisation shows that the turbulent wake behind the wheels is directed outwards by the side pod, still affecting surrounding regions.
theCar.concaveSidePod: Our first idea was to extend the ramp to its maximum width while retaining the concave profile.
theCar.largelyConvexSidePod: In the following version, the ramp was reshaped from concave into a largely convex form, which resulted in a reduction in drag.
theCar.lcspwasf: Building on this, a third configuration added a side foil to guide the airflow more effectively around the rear wheel but this led to a slightly higher drag due to interferences between the side foil and the side pod.
theCar.weightReductionText: As there is a fixed amount of force emitted from the CO2 cartridge, it is important to make the car as lightweight as possible while still maintaining the minimum weight of 55 grams. Newton ’s second law of motion (F = ma) describes that the less an object weighs, the higher is its acceleration when applying a certain force. To reach the minimum weight of the cars, we make them hollow on the inside to save weight. As the freedom of design is very good, we use SLS printing to produce our chassis. It is easier than milling it with polyurethane (special hard foam block) because there are less parameters to consider.
theCar.stabilityComponentsText: To continually make sure that the wheels, the halo and other components are stable enough to withstand the pressure of impact, we virtually test them with the FEA. The Finite Element Analysis is a simulation that predicts how structures react to forces like stress, heat and vibration. Complex models are divided into smaller elements, forces applying on the car are defined and equations, considering the structural integrity of materials, are solved. After solving the simulation, it is shown if the material is strong enough to withstand a certain force.

whatIsStemracing.title: What is STEM Racing?
whatIsStemracing.text: STEM Racing, formerly known as F1 in Schools, is the world’s largest STEM competition for students aged 11 to 19. Participants compete in various categories, including:
whatIsStemracing.text1: Designing and manufacturing a miniature Formula 1 car powered by CO2 cartridges
whatIsStemracing.text2: Creating three detailed portfolios (Project Management, Enterprise, and Design & Engineering)
whatIsStemracing.text5: Each project element is judged and awarded points. The car is scored based on race times and results from the scruitineering process. The overall winner is determined by the total number of points achieved. The competition consists of several levels: Regional, National, and World Finals. Winning teams at each level qualify for the next stage.

gofundme.whyWeNeedYourHelp:
Why we need your help:
With competing, there are significant costs involved:
gofundme.registrationFees: We need to pay around 10,600€ for registration
gofundme.travelCosts: About 19,000€ for our rooms at the official competition hotel
gofundme.whyWeNeedYourHelpPart2: Our calculated total budget will be around 50k. We are a team of six 10th grade students and cannot cover these expenses on our own. We are actively seeking sponsors and supporters - and this is where we need you. We must book our rooms in the official competition hotel within the next 3 weeks. If we can't secure the necessary funds in time, we won't be able to participate in the World Finals.
